title: HW0 Q4

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Problem context post:</paragraph><paragraph>This is a problem whose mechanics are all review. However, many if not most of you will not have seen all of these specific facts. These are some key ideas for bridging classical ML and Deep Learning phenomena.<break/><break/>Perspective (e) for example was apparently discovered quite recently for such an elementary and fundamental fact. It appeared in both <link href="https://www.jmlr.org/papers/v21/19-844.html">https://www.jmlr.org/papers/v21/19-844.html</link> (July 2020, Section 2.4) and <link href="https://doi.org/10.1109/JSAIT.2020.2984716">https://doi.org/10.1109/JSAIT.2020.2984716</link> (Mar 2020, Supplemental B.4) as a part of the efforts to understand what is going on in deep learning --- where we often have more parameters than training points.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Problem context post:

This is a problem whose mechanics are all review. However, many if not most of you will not have seen all of these specific facts. These are some key ideas for bridging classical ML and Deep Learning phenomena.

Perspective (e) for example was apparently discovered quite recently for such an elementary and fundamental fact. It appeared in both https://www.jmlr.org/papers/v21/19-844.html (July 2020, Section 2.4) and https://doi.org/10.1109/JSAIT.2020.2984716 (Mar 2020, Supplemental B.4) as a part of the efforts to understand what is going on in deep learning --- where we often have more parameters than training points.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I'm reading the JMLR article! Thank you for sharing the math section, I might end up reading the rest of the article later.<break/><break/>I'm confused about the wording of parts (e) and (f). How do you want us to show that (2) is another form of ridge regression? Does that involve using the pseudo-inverse as they do in the article? If so, how is that different from the first subpart of (f)? </paragraph><paragraph>I think that I understand the math in the article that you shared but am still confused on how to demonstrate the knowledge on the homework questions. </paragraph></document>
comments.document:
I'm reading the JMLR article! Thank you for sharing the math section, I might end up reading the rest of the article later.

I'm confused about the wording of parts (e) and (f). How do you want us to show that (2) is another form of ridge regression? Does that involve using the pseudo-inverse as they do in the article? If so, how is that different from the first subpart of (f)? 

I think that I understand the math in the article that you shared but am still confused on how to demonstrate the knowledge on the homework questions.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>You need to solve the problem without reading the article. Don't overcomplicate things. I was just pointing students to the articles so you could see how recently all this stuff was done --- that was meant to be inspiring not intimidating. </paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: You need to solve the problem without reading the article. Don't overcomplicate things. I was just pointing students to the articles so you could see how recently all this stuff was done --- that was meant to be inspiring not intimidating.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Hi! did anyone get $\argmin_W (||y-Wx||^2 + \lambda^{3/2} ||w||^2)$ for part (c)? That is what I got and its off by the $\lambda$ exponent</paragraph></document>

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I would suggest looking at how/where you are multiplying $\lambda$ when solving for the MAP solution. </paragraph></document>

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>For pt e i used the min norm equation I derived in 3 to show that the minimizers are the same but this ended up being exactly what f is asking. Confused on how we should be solving e differently</paragraph></document>

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>I would start by decomposing $\eta$ into two sub vectors, and work towards showing that the formulation of equation (2) is just another form of ridge regression and how $\eta^*$'s first $d$ coordinates correspond to the ridge regression solution. What you are saying is to just use the answer directly.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: I would start by decomposing $\eta$ into two sub vectors, and work towards showing that the formulation of equation (2) is just another form of ridge regression and how $\eta^*$'s first $d$ coordinates correspond to the ridge regression solution. What you are saying is to just use the answer directly.
